metadata.case_name: Sohel Singh & Ors. v. Amar Singh & Ors.

facts.text: Pedigree: Milkhi -> Himmat Singh -> Gulab Singh (alive in 1885), Mehtab Singh (dead, sons including Mangal Singh testator), Fattu (dead, son Leekar dead); Mangal Singh's descendants include plaintiffs Sohel Singh (Pl1), Waryam Singh (Pl2), Shiv Singh (Plf No.3); defendants: Amar Singh (Deft No.1), Ajaib Singh (Deft No.2), Karnail Singh (Deft No.3), Puran Singh (Deft No.4).
On August 11, 1947, Mangal Singh executed a will bequeathing the property in dispute to Amar Singh (defendant No. 1).
Mutation of Mangal Singh's estate effected in the name of Amar Singh on April 10, 1948 by mutation No. 733.

Plaintiffs Sohel Singh, Waryam Singh and Shiv Singh brought a suit for declaration that the will was ineffective against them and for possession of certain parcels of land mutated in the name of Amar Singh. Allegations: will made under undue influence, coercion and fraud; land was ancestral qua the defendants.
Suit dismissed by trial court holding that it was not proved that the execution of the will was procured by undue influence, coercion or fraud and that the land had not been proved to be ancestral.

District Judge on appeal held that out of 66 Kanals 2 Marlas of land in dispute, an area of 28 Kanals 3 Marlas was ancestral as it was held by Himmat Singh, father of Mehtab Singh the common ancestor. Noted Mehtab Singh predeceased Himmat Singh but no proof.
High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 747 of 1951 dated September 12, 1955 reversed District Judge and restored trial court decree, dismissing plaintiffs' suit.

Out of land claimed, 20 Kanals 19 Marlas (Para A-2) acquired by Mangal Singh by pre-emption; another portion his self-acquired mortgagee land. Dispute confined to certain Khasra numbers fallen to share of testator in consolidation proceedings in lieu of his share.
Excerpt P.W. 6/1 by Special Kanungo: some Khasra numbers traced to possession of Himmat Singh s/o Milkhi in 1849; some to Himmat Singh and others; remaining to strangers.
District Judge traced history of each Khasra number and decreed only those held by Himmat Singh, area 28 Kanals 3 Marlas.
At first regular settlement, land decreed held by Himmat Singh.

Revenue pedigree shows in 1885 three branches descending from Himmat Singh (Gulab Singh alive, sons of Mehtab Singh, Leekar s/o Fattu) held khewat Nos. 34, 35, 36 equal in area, each paying Rs. 13 land revenue.
Ex. P.W. 6/1 shows Khata No. 34 held by sons of Mehtab Singh jointly in equal shares.

legal_issues.text: Whether 28 Kanals 3 Marlas out of the land in suit is proved to be ancestral qua the appellants.

petitioner_arguments.text: The land in dispute was ancestral qua the defendants; will ineffective as Mangal Singh had no power to bequeath ancestral property.

respondent_arguments.text: Land was not ancestral unless shown held by common ancestor Mehtab Singh; no revenue entry showing possession by Mehtab Singh.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Attar Singh v. Thakar Singh (1908) L.R. 35 I.A. 206

respondent_arguments.text: Land consolidated; ancestral and non-ancestral mixed up, cannot identify ancestral portion.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in interfering with District Judge's finding that 28 Kanals 3 Marlas was ancestral; land held by Himmat Singh at first settlement and in 1849; revenue pedigree 1885 shows equal shares among three branches from Himmat Singh; Khata 34 held jointly by sons of Mehtab.
court_reasoning.key_observation: History of land clearly shows ancestral nature in hands of descendants.

court_reasoning.text: Land ancestral even if held by remote ancestor (Himmat Singh) not immediate common ancestor (Mehtab Singh), if history indicates inheritance not acquisition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Attar Singh v. Thakar Singh does not support respondents' submission.

court_reasoning.text: Post-consolidation, portion of consolidated area corresponding to ancestral land area remains ancestral.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Followed Haveldar Mihan Singh v. Piara Singh.

holdings.text: 28 Kanals 3 Marlas of land proved ancestral qua appellants; High Court erred in reversing District Judge.

precedents_cited.relevance: Respondents cited to argue land not ancestral without possession by immediate common ancestor; court held does not support as remote ancestor sufficient with inheritance history.

precedents_cited.case_name: Haveldar Mihan Singh v. Piara Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Portion of consolidated area corresponding to ancestral land remains ancestral.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Law
statutes_cited.relevance: Ancestral property cannot be bequeathed by will if coparcenary interest exists.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, holding that the High Court erred in interfering with the District Judge's finding that 28 Kanals 3 Marlas of land was ancestral qua the appellants, reversing the High Court and restoring the District Court's decree in that regard.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that specified land is ancestral; suit decreed for that portion.

key_quotes.text: "It is through their father, as heir of the abovenamed Dhanna Singh, that the plaintiffs claimed, and unless the lands came to Dhanna Singh by descent from a lineal male ancestor in the male line through whom the plaintiffs also in like manner claimed, they are not deemed ancestral in Hindu law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Attar Singh v. Thakar Singh distinguished by Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "the history of the land which has been referred to above clearly shows the ancestral nature of the land in the hand of the descendants, the parties to the present appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on ancestral character despite remote ancestor.
